data.title: Takes all resources - other programs stop working
data.body:
After upgrading to the latest version (1.0.3) I frequently face the issue that Atom takes all the resources (new MacBook Pro; Chrome with a lot of tabs open and XCode) and other programs suddenly stop working:
-Node.js: error with code EAGAIN
-No new terminal: bash: fork: Resource temporarily unavailable
-Chrome: no new tab

As soon as I close Atom everything runs smoothly again. Also I already tried to increase the `ulimit -n` but nothing helped so far. Has someone else also experienced these issues? Is it Atom itself or maybe a system setting? 

P.S: just in this second Atom also stopped working and the error report says the following (creating this issue from within Atom is also not possible as Atom does not react to this click):

```
/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/task.js:120
Hide Stack Trace
TypeError: undefined is not a function
  at Task.module.exports.Task.send (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/task.js:120:27)
  at Task.module.exports.Task.start (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/task.js:111:12)
  at Function.module.exports.Task.once (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/task.js:23:18)
  at GitRepository.module.exports.GitRepository.refreshStatus (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/git-repository.js:398:37)
  at /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/git-repository.js:77:26
```

data.title: The scroll bar doesn't respond sometimes in zip files
data.body:
I'm very happy that Atom actually supports viewing zip files (among many other things). But, there's some trouble while scrolling a pane. Here's a (~7 MB) GIF demonstrating what I did:

![GIF](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6691262/9026385/ec12a0aa-394a-11e5-83f4-f8e492736e5b.gif)
- I can click and drag the scroll bar from the start of the zip file (I can also use my mouse wheel).
- But, I can't click & drag the scroll bar when it's somewhere in the middle. When I do that, the scroll bar simply goes upwards! (as you can see)

**Note:** This works only while viewing zip files. Other files work just fine...

**OS**: Ubuntu 14.04 (x64)
**Atom version:** 1.0.0

<sup>**Sidenote:** I use Atom almost everyday and it's really helpful as a text editor. Thanks for making it possible! :)</sup>

data.title: Bracket highlighting incorrect
data.body:
Where there are multiple parens, currently, paren matching at the end-paren (ie close parens) highlights the paren to the right, but it should be the paren to the left.

So, say I have this:
(((:after-clone-fn val)X))

...and my cursor is at the X position, then the paren that _should_ be matched is the one to the left. The one that _is_ matched, tho, is the one to the right.

This doesn't seem correct behaviour to me. (FWIW, I'm editing clojure code at the moment).

data.title: Add text color to atom-workspace
data.body:
Currently the `atom-workspace` background-color uses `@app-background-color`, but text color isn't defined and falls back to Bootstrap's default color of `#333`. This can make text hard to read with dark themes.

This PR adds `color: @text-color;` which should match the background.

data.title: search bar is too eager
data.body:
When I start searching inside a large file (or in a small file with long lines that atom hates so much), 
atom starts to lag because it immediately scans the whole file even for the first character. 

let's say I want to search in a 2k line javascript file for something like **if (a) {**.
atom will start searching the whole file for all **if**, then for all **if (**, all **if (a** and so on. 
that can get really laggy.  If I want to search for something that starts with a whitespace I can even crash atom when there are thousands of whitespaces in one file. 

I know if you type very fast you don't get that problem. but unless you search for words like **function** etc. you won't be fast enough to keep atom from auto searching..

my suggestion: don't automatically search inputs below 2 characters. if search for just one single character is ever necessary, hitting the return key or clicking the find button should not be too much to ask. or include a settings option to disable auto search below a certain number of characters.

data.title: Option for zero-indexed line numbers
data.body: I've always wanted zero-indexed line numbers. That's what I'm used to: other than nutty environments like Excel/AppleScript/Matlab/etc, arrays are always zero-indexed. But perplexingly no programmer's editor supports them. Zero-indexed line numbers make counting lines, sets of lines, and newline characters easier, since the line number is literally the index of the line. The correspondence is so well suited that pointer/index arithmetic carries over seamlessly. And this would be exceptionally easy to implement in the core.

data.title: atom config file watching breaks on linux if dropbox is changing the files
data.body:
## Repro Steps
1. move your config.cson to dropbox and make a symbolic in `~/.atom`
2. open atom
3. open the config.cson with another editor
4. change something, e.g. the theme

**Expected:** atom picks up the change and changes the theme
**Actual:** atom picks up the change and changes the theme
1. move your config.cson to dropbox and make a symbolic in `~/.atom`
2. open atom
3. change the config.cson on another computer

**Expected:** atom picks up the change and changes the theme
**Actual:** atom does not pick up the change and changes the theme. Interestingly it refuses to pick up any changes to that config anymore, even local ones, unless atom is reloaded.

This is true for all config files.

The editor (having the config file open in atom) is picking up the changes from dropbox, so I suppose the file watching for the config files and the one for open buffers is implemented differently, right?
## Command History

```
     -2:15.7 ready (#document)
     -0:02.2 command-palette:toggle (atom-text-editor.editor.is-focused)
```

data.title: Feature request: add a package.json config file
data.body: I think it would be very useful to have a `package.json` similar to Node for managing all additionally installed packages in Atom.  This way on new machines, rather than have to copy the `packages` folder, all we would need to do is provide the `package.json` file and Atom could read that and install any packages with their respective versions.  Very similar to Node and NPM, and seeing as how Atom is built on that I think it would only be fitting to incorporate the same structure :)

data.title: Set App User Model ID on Win32
data.body:
This PR set the App User Model ID to match what Squirrel.Windows configures the shortcut to be, which should resolve #7374.

Normally, our App User Model ID is unset, but certain Windows features require an explicit App User Model ID (jump lists and notifications). To solve this Generally™, we rig Squirrel.Windows to configure this in the shortcut, which means that the Browser process will inherit this value.

However, because Chromium forks and the process that actually creates the window isn't the same one, and App User Model IDs don't inherit, our renderer process ends up being the _default_ one (which is effectively the path to the EXE). We fix this in https://github.com/atom/electron/pull/2175, but we still need to tell Electron what the initial name should be.

data.title: Atom does not recognize git worktree repositories
data.body:
When `git-repository-provider.coffee` searches for the git repository it looks for the `.git` directory, however `git worktree` creates repositories that have `.git` file that has `gitdir: path/to/gitdir` as contents. As a result atom cannot currently work with repositories created with `git worktree`. Unfortunately even making `.git` a symlink doesn't work, since worktree gitdir doesn't have `objects` or `refs` subdirectories.

Atom should recognize `.git` files that start with `gitdir:` as valid git repositories.
